Germany, Canada and France have expressed interest in continuing with parallel financing. Project Objectives and Description: The operation would have: (a) four development obiectives: (i) reduce poverty by improving access to basic urban services; (ii) develop the local private sector by increasing the competitiveness of construction and consulting firns; (iii) support an initial pilot phase of decentralization so that local governments can better plan and manage urban infrastructure assets and services, and improve resource mobilization; and (iv) improve public sector management by using transparent procedures and delegation of project authority; and (b) three project objectives: (i) create new temporary employment opportunities in rapidly growing urban and peni- urban areas; (ii) help municipalities create or rehabilitate basic, urgent infrastructure assets; and (iii) develop municipal capacity to manage these assets and help MOI to play its tutorship role. The project will have two components: (a) a program of poverty- oriented, labor-intensive works sub-projects (US$20.5 million) in participating cities, consisting of rehabilitation or construction of urban facilities of various categories; and (b) capacity building (pilot decentralization): (i) at the municipal level (US$2 million), to enhance managerial capacities through the introduction of municipal management tools including provision of equipment and training; and (ii) at the national
 iv Mauritania. Urban Infrastructure and Pilot Decentralization Project. SAR. level (US$1.5 million), to strengthen the monitoring capacity of the MOI and to prepare new municipal regulations. Project Benefits and Risks: The program of labor-intensive public works (US$20.5 million) consists of four categories of sub-projects: (i) economic sub-projects (approximately US$6 million) which would have an economic rate of return (ERR) of at least 12 percent and the net present value (NPV) is expected to reach a minimum of US$1.2 million; average actual ERRs, under the ongoing CCEP, have been 31 percent for roads, 42 percent for protection against sand encroachment, 25 percent for drainage works, 17 percent for public buildings; (ii) social sub-projects (approximately US$8 million) for which ERR would not be calculated for each operation but which would meet sectoral priority criteria for sectoral projects that have an average ERR above 10 percent; (iii) revenue eaming projects (approximately US$4 million), which would have a minimum financial rate of return of 15 percent and an estimated NPV of US$0.8 million, actual average financial rate of retum under CCEP was 33, and (iv) municipal management sub-projects (approximately US$2 million) which would bring additional fiscal revenue over the next three years of 200 percent of the investment costs and have an estimated cumulated NPV of US$3.8 million. These amounts do not include other tangible and important, but unmeasured benefits such as: (a) savings in travel time to jobs, schools and health facilities; (b) training of unskilled labor; (c) building the capacity of local consulting and construction enterprises; and (d) improving operational efficiency of municipal govemments. The latter would be monitored through the Municipal Contracts, annual performance audits and municipal performance indicators. Over the longer term, the institutional and policy reformns supported by the project are expected to expand the decentralization program beyond the pilot phase by building municipal management capacity and mobilizing local resources. This is not a high-risk project. There are four minor risks intemal to the proposed operation. First, on the resource mobilization side, municipalities could fail to increase their revenue base and tax collection. To mitigate this risk, a gradual approach to local resource mobilization and a study on national/local revenue sharing will be implemented. Second, on the counterpart funds side, the Govemment and participating municipalities may not provide their contributions. To avoid this risk, the project provides for up-front contributions before the signing of all civil works contracts. Evidence from the ongoing CCEP indicates that strong endorsement from municipalities will continue. Third, the program may further skew regional inequities. To mitigate this risk, the eligibility criteria for regional balance will be included and refined in the Regional Development Fund. And fourth, on the institutional side, the DCL may not play its expanded monitoring and mentoring role. To mitigate this risk, additional institution support would be provided by bilateral agencies, notably France and Germany. Exogenous risks include a

The impact of these two risks was assessed and the conclusion was reached that it is very unlikely that Government will backslide on economic management or on the institutional and political gains already achieved in municipal elections and decentralization. Poverty: Reducing poverty and unemployment are among Mauritania's and IDA's priority goals. The 1994 poverty profile surveys conducted in Mauritania stress that 57 percent of the population lives below the poverty threshold (UM 32,000 or US$370 per capita per year) and that the poor have limited access to basic services infrastructure (safe water, sanitation, schools, health centers). The project, therefore, aims at improving access of the poor to these basic services. The use of new management tools (priority investment programs, performance indicators, eligibility criteria) will help municipalities better identify the right priorities and target poor areas by providing improved access to basic infrastructure and services, such as safe water, sanitation, drainage, schools and clinics. Other expected benefits are: a direct impact by creating about 45,000 man- months of temporary employment and an indirect impact by creating permanent jobs due to the shift from capital intensive to labor intensive construction methods. Amex 2 Page 1 / 20 Annex 2a ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF MAURITANIA MINISTRY OF INTERIOR, POSTS AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS DIRECTORATE OF LOCAL GOVERNMENTS COMMUNICATION TO COUNCIL OF MINISTERS SUBJECT: MUNICIPAL POLICY STATEIENT INTRODUCTION When restructuring began in 1984, the President of the Republic pledged to establish democratic institutions in Mauritania. This commitment was supported by all strata of the population. Accordingly, in 1986, local government elections were organized at the regional level, and subsequently, in 1987 and 1988, at the departmental level and in the rural municipalities. The intention behind this measure was, on the one hand, to provide all population groups with experience of the democratic process through their exercise of the right to vote and organization of electoral campaigns, and, on the other, to give substance to the democratic option by demonstrating its importance as an element in the country's general development. While this was the intention of the country's highest authorities, local structures and local elected officials were not prepared technically for this transfer of power or its anticipated contribution to sound local governance. Difficulties of a physical, institutional, professional, and financial nature clearly have to be overcome if the municipal councils are to function normally and regularly from the outset. Other constraints are ascribable mainly to the general environment. For instance, the Directorate of Local Governments (DCL) and the administrative authorities, whose appointed mission is to advise, monitor, and regulate, are not themselves sufficiently well equipped to carry out these tasks. The situation is further complicated by a series of other problems, all of which need not be enumerated here but which include the following examples: * The supervisory authority (DCL) lacking the physical, legal, technical, and human resources to exercise effective supervision and to provide guidance and coordination; * Difficulties in putting laws and regulations into effect, a result of insufficient training among elected officials in a sphere of activity new to them; * Municipalities without resident mayors and municipal councils who do not meet; * Conflicts of all types between administrative authorities and mayors;

In these circumstances, solutions are needed that will allow the municipal institution to be protected and developed - an institution that is of primordial political importance among the country's constitutional institutions in the election of the Senate and in the nomination, on the basis of 50 signatures of municipal councilors, of candidates for the office of Head of State. It is thus imperative to make every effort to orient action by the municipalities toward integrated local development that will allow all dimensions of the problems facing them to be addressed. This is equivalent to saying that each recovery action must inevitably involve: • rehabilitation of local government finances; * rational use and redeployment of the municipal work force; D introduction of simple financial legislation; - commitment by the administrative authorities to better supervision of the municipalities; - improved management; * training for elected officials; - reorganization and reinforcement of the supervisory authority. The objective of the municipal policy statement set out in the attached document submitted for your approval is to generate solutions to the problems outlined above, which hinder the advance of our municipalities. Annexe 2 Page 3 / 20 MUNICIPAL POLICY STATEMENT The Government of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania began democratization through administrative decentralization in 1986 with a view to promoting the exercise of democracy and fostering local government through participatory methods conducive to good governance. The Government is convinced that, in the current context, development goes hand in hand with decentralized administration, especially given the advent of democracy in 1991. The democracy and decentralization accomplished thus far have heightened the confidence of local stakeholders and international donors, which will increase the chances of successful nationwide decentralization. The determination of the Government to introduce decentralization and make it a permanent feature is behind the formulation of this municipal development policy statement, which must in practice result in a transfer of functions to the municipal governments and an improvement in their institutional and organizational environment. This policy statement also aims at fostering the conditions that will enable the municipalities to increase their financial capabilities and implement investment programs centered on the construction, rehabilitation and upkeep of urban infrastructure. Meeting future challenges in the realm of infrastructure' is not merely an exercise of simple accounting - that is, preparing an inventory of existing infrastructure and calculating necessary investment on the basis of past trends. Instead, all inefficiencies in both investment and the supply of services must be tackled and user demands more efficiently addressed. Efforts to increase infrastructure must be accompanied by an improvement in services. It is in that spirit that the proposals contained in this document seek to ensure the necessary legal and financial conditions. These will involve: I. Municipal assets: * infrastructure management' * authority to contract * introduction of performance criteria for access to investment. II. MUNICIPAL ASSETS (a) Infrastructure Management l The term infrastructure in this context refers to the whole range of fixed assets (roads, municipal facilities, property) envisaged by Article 2 of Ordonnance 289.87.

The Government will therefore do its utmost to promote implementation of the provisions already been set forth in the basic legislation governing the decentralization of the country. That implementation could consist of action to: - Amend existing legislation by taking into account the particular nature of the type of municipality. In this connection, a study could be undertaken to propose solutions geared to specifically local circumstances; - Establish agreements between urban municipalities and supervisory authorities for transfer of goods and services that by their nature are of local interest. In this connection, clear measures governing municipal assets should be introduced as soon as possible so that local governments are aware of exactly what means are at their disposal and the possibilities for sound management of their resources; - Disseminate informational and educational texts, circulars and documents so that local elected officials understand their areas of jurisdiction with a view to better management of municipal assets and judicious utilization of the legal means at their disposal; - Hold training seminars and workshops on case studies, and encourage exchanges of experience among elected officials. (b) Authority to Contract In practical terms, real decentralization entails the authority to contract - in other words, the legal and financial capacity to commit public funds. This is in itself an area of expertise that is new to many elected municipal officials who are inexperienced with it, especially because in the past local infrastructure loans have been small, or non-existent. As the municipalities play the dual role of contracting authority and operator, through the design of urban works and services and their execution on force account, municipal teams have very divergent levels of familiarity with the specifics of project management. First of all, the decisionmaking role of municipalities in project management should be reaffirmed, provided that the necessary funding is available, even if authority to contract, in terms of technical tasks, can be largely delegated. (c) Introduction of Performance Criteria for Access to Investment This new approach aims at rationalizing municipal action and management, given present limited means and vast needs.

RESOURCE MOBILIZATION Implementation of this policy requires reforms in taxation and municipal organization: D taxation • financing of local development • operation of institutions D municipal action. (a) Taxation Local taxation is inadequate and ad hoc, in terms of both the tax base and collection system. The new policy will therefore seek to streamline the tax system overall and adapt it to actual circumstances, with a view to maximizing revenue. The reforms should target both the tax base and collection procedures. Tax basg Taxes and fees should be streamlined and collection performance improved. Additionally, municipal taxes should be standardized. Tax collection Given its present poor performance record, revision of the municipal collection system is critical. Regulations must be simplified, functions reshuffled, the exact fields of action of the national and municipal tax authorities redefined, and incentives to optimize tax receipts introduced. Under the revised, simplified and standardized tax system, the central govermnent and its decentralized offices should be responsible for the collection of all national and municipal taxes, and the municipalities released from all tax collection functions. This administrative specialization would have the advantage of increasing the coherence of the tax system, improving the mobilization of management tools, encouraging better review of disputes, and facilitating depersonalization of relations between tax officials and taxpayers. It is also recommended that financial incentives be offered collection agents, and that other incentives be offered to taxpayers to encourage them to meet their tax obligations by themselves. Cooeration With regard to the mobilization of international resources, the bases for aid coordination must be laid. To that end, access to bilateral and multilateral aid should be enhanced. This can be achieved if the Ministry of Planning and the Decentralized Cooperation Office of the Ministry of the Interior provide information on progress with projects under way and on sector studies that have been carried out or are in preparation. Remote communities without access to "stand-alone" cooperation assistance, owing to their limited ability to identify and negotiate such aid, should receive special support. (c) Operation of Institutions Local accounting systems suffer from overly complicated and unnecessary procedures and are not sufficiently transparent. Excessively formal, current municipal accounting systems involve too much red tape and are not tailored to the reality of most municipalities. Consequently, they do not allow for optimal expenditure structures and, more generally, impede management of the municipal entity. Budget and administration simplification is therefore needed, especially for the rural municipalities. Personnel Issues of employment and status of municipal personnel must be discussed as part of the larger picture of municipal functions and capabilities, especially since the 'auxiliary employees' category has been eliminated by the new civil service legislation. The organization chart should be adapted to the activity and means of the municipality.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Urban Infrastructure and Pilot Decentralization Project are to: 1) create new temporary employment opportunities in rapidly growing urban and peri-urban areas; 2) help municipalities create or rehabilitate basic, urgent infrastructure assets; and 3) develop municipal capacity to manage these assets and help the Ministry of Interior, Posts, and Telecommunications (MOI) to play its tutorship role. The project will have two components: 1) a program of poverty-oriented, labor-intensive works sub-projects which will fall into the following categories: (a) economic infrastructure projects; (b) social infrastructure projects; (c) municipal income-generating projects; and (d) municipal management projects; and 2) capacity building (pilot decentralization) including: (a) infrastructure planning and urban space management; (b) management reform; (c) training of municipal staff and elected officials; (d) capacity strengthening of the Directorale of Local Government of MOI (DCL), the Decentralization Technical Coordination Committee (DTCC), and the Association of Mayors; and (e) reform of the legal and regulatory municipal framework.
